channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Comedian and actor Ramy Youssef on when he began to see his parents as people
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Comedian and Actor Ramy Youssef reflects on when he began to see his parents as people.

item.title: South Korean opposition party candidate Lee Jae-myung wins presidential election
item.description: After months of political turmoil, South Korea has elected Lee Jae-myung, of the main liberal party, as the new president.

item.title: CEO of Doctors Without Borders weighs in on violence at Gaza food distribution site
item.description: On Tuesday morning, more than two dozen people were killed as they tried to collect emergency food aid near a distribution site in Gaza -- the third mass-casualty event in three days.

item.title: Tulsa mayor wants private trust fund as form of reparation for Tulsa Massacre
item.description: The mayor of Tulsa says he wants to set up a private trust to help descendants of survivors of the 1921 race riots that mark the city to this day.

item.title: ICE arrest after false traffic stop may pave way to legal status of 19-year-old
item.description: A 19-year-old immigrant who was arrested in Georgia after a traffic stop may now have a chance to gain legal residency status.

item.title: Rural library funding threats
item.description: For years, the Institute of Museum and Library Services has supported them. However, cuts by the Trump administration could jeopardize the future of rural libraries in particular.

item.title: European CPACs show the growing unity of the global far-right
item.description: Members of the Trump administration mingled with far-right leaders from around the world at two Conservative Political Action conferences in Europe last week.

item.title: 'The L Word' was groundbreaking. Its stars say nothing has filled its place since
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Leisha Hailey and Kate Moennig, authors of So Gay For You and stars of The L Word, about their decades-long friendship and the show's lasting impact on culture.

item.title: Would-be home buyers are staying on the sidelines
item.description: Some folks who planned to buy a home this spring have changed their plans, citing political and economic uncertainty.

item.title: Why Black Catholics in New Orleans feel a special connection to Pope Leo XIV
item.description: A genealogist has discovered that Pope Leo XIV has Creole roots in New Orleans, where Black Catholics are now celebrating "Pope Leo of the 7th Ward."
